Message.Title: Is Intel Going Back Into The Memory Business?
Message.Msg: "Now my speculation is: Intel has developed a 14nm NAND cell that would shrink the 128Gb chip size to 100 square millimeters. A 450mm fab would produce over twice the square inches of silicon that a 300mm facility would. Thus a 1.2 million wafer 450mm plant would produce about 1.4 billion 128Gb 14nm NAND chips. That would be one $10 billion factory with the output of four $5 billion 300mm plants. Can Intel make money in the NAND business? Let's just figure a $7000 cost for those 450mm wafers. The 128Gb chips would have to sell for about $14 to Intel itself or the world at large in order to deliver a SSD at $1 per GB. Those big wafers could produce about 1200 100 sq mm chips. At $14 each, the wafer is worth about $16,800 against a $7000 cost is 58% gross margin. When the depreciation is out of that factory, the gross margins would reach into the high 60% range. There are a lot of numbers to be digested here, but the bottom line is that Intel can make a lot of money on the NAND memory that they are going to need for those SSDs in Ultrabooks. And, no small thing, Intel would be first to 450mm wafer production. Just another reason to own Intel." [I found Russ Fischer's speculation on the memory business very interesting - primarily because of the discussion relating to 450mm wafers. This is yet another area in which Intel's leadership will allow them economics that no one else in the business will have for a long time...]

Topic.Title: Intel Cuts Manufacturing Costs With Big Data

Message.Msg: "A lot of what we're doing is pulling log files out of manufacturing and test machines," said Kasabian. "Across our entire factory network, we're talking about 5 terabytes an hour. So it's very big volume." By capturing and analyzing this information, Intel can determine when a specific step in one of its manufacturing processes starts to deviate from normal tolerances.... SPC Statistical process control (SPC) is a method of quality control which uses statistical methods. SPC is applied in order to monitor and control a process. Monitoring and controlling the process ensures that it operates at its full potential. At its full potential, the process can make as much conforming product as possible with a minimum (if not an elimination) of waste (rework or trash). SPC can be applied to any process where the "conforming product" (product meeting specifications) output can be measured. Key tools used in SPC include control charts; a focus on continuous improvement; and the design of experiments. An example of a process where SPC is applied is manufacturing lines.

Topic.Title: Is Intel Going Back Into The Memory Business?

Message.Msg: "Now my speculation is: Intel has developed a 14nm NAND cell that would shrink the 128Gb chip size to 100 square millimeters" Intel NAND business focuses on Enterprise SSD - specifically SLC because of reliability . I think the author is off track. Intel 's plate is more than full and they should fully concentrtate on logic and not get sidetracked by NAND

Topic.Title: Intel Cuts Manufacturing Costs With Big Data

Message.Msg: SPC is nothing really new - but Intel refined it and enhanced it. Six Sigma is a set of tools and strategies for process improvement originally developed by Motorola in 1985.[1][2] Six Sigma became well known after Jack Welch made it a central focus of his business strategy at General Electric in 1995,[3] and today it is used in different sectors of industry.[4] Six Sigma seeks to improve the quality of process outputs by identifying and removing the causes of defects (errors) and minimizing variability in manufacturing and business processes.[5] It uses a set of quality management methods, including statistical methods, and creates a special infrastructure of people within the organization ("Champions", "Black Belts", "Green Belts", "Orange Belts", etc.) who are experts in these very complex methods.[5] Each Six Sigma project carried out within an organization follows a defined sequence of steps and has quantified financial targets (cost reduction and/or profit increase).[5]

Message.Title: News media gets it wrong
Message.Msg: These news media just seem to repeat one another without any kind of analysis. Here's an example: "It (Intel's TV service) will compete with heavyweights like Apple Inc, Amazon Inc and Google Inc " Wait a second here...Does Apple, Amazon or Google offer live TV streaming? NO. Intel will be the FIRST company to offer Live streaming TV. Let's get that straight. Intel will not be competing with these companies. Intel is offering an alternative to the cable operators who are refusing to work with Apple, Amazon and Google. Intel intends to work with these companies by providing the Live TV service to them in exchange for using Intel hardware.

Topic.Title: Intel Cuts Manufacturing Costs With Big Data

Message.Msg: SPC was first used on a sustaining basis by Western Electric in the late 1920's and 1930's, led by Dr. Walter Shewart. When Motorola started having quality problems in the 80's, some smart people decided to research and see how phone people made high quality phones back in the "old days", and low and behold they found the methods used at Western Electric (the people who make the phones and equipment for the ATT system - a government granted monopoly, by the way) were pretty smart about it. SPC has great application at Intel - high volume production that requires extraordinary tight tolerances - exactly what SPC is best at. The danger with SPC is getting people to change processes once they get processes "in control" - use of SPC can reinforce a natural resistance to change. This is a problem with all businesses to one degree or another, but in spades with tech - "controlled" production processes in the context of an industry where change is frequent.

Message.Title: seriously, will this thing ever see $25 this year?
Message.Msg: All the hype on tablets, mobile, etc., is ultimately only worth a few percent of bottom line. The mobile mkts are commodotized and don't really represent a large revenue stream..maybe $6 Billion total to the chip makers. Tablets may be better, but probably low margin. This is, at best, offsetting the very real implosion of PC's. I have to travel this week and dread lugging my dell inspiron around (what a pos that company and its products are...almost a MSFT in shoddiness) . So we're taking 5 steps forward and 4 back..or is it the other way around? And, fact is, that's been the Intel story for the past decade. Yes, they are the best, but always margins are shrinking. I just don't see any explosive catalyst here, and always the present danger from a Samsung, or a QCOM, or ? Give me $25 and I'm outa here.

Topic.Title: seriously, will this thing ever see $25 this year?

Message.Msg: Sure... 1. DCG growth should come in at ~10-15% this year. Very high operating margin here, which drives some very nice earnings leverage. 2. PC refresh cycle "reset" has pretty much hit, so I expect that after the bottom we saw put in during Q3 and Q4 2012, the PC segment should resume its normal, low single digit growth. 3. Opportunity in smartphones is quite large, especially as Intel provides both modem/baseband silicon and has begun offering competitive apps processors. Even if Intel grabs ~20% market share, that's several hundred million units of both apps processor + modem, so think ~$20-$30+ per phone. Across ~200M+ phones, this is not chump change. 4. Opportunity in tablets is even larger. Intel will own the windows 8 tablets, and it will also be a major player in the Android space. Lots of unit volume here to drive growth, especially as I do not believe that tablets are replacing PCs - this is all upside. 5. Longer term, Intel Custom Foundry should add nicely to the top and bottom lines. Lots of growth drivers ahead, but investors here need to be patient.

Message.Title: ARM Technicals
Message.Msg: ARM will start the day down 92 cents which is 2.2 percent but it was down 3.3 on the London exchange. The news of East's retirement without any prior notice or speculation looks like a PR disaster. The fact that they don't have a replacement candidate ready and have to elevate Segars the president into the position indicates that this was not a planned event. It will be interesting to get some more color on the retirement. If the pattern of the previous days holds, then we will see further declines during the day. Another 50 cents would break the $40 barrier and then it becomes a much more slippery slope. All in all, it looks like a pretty ham-handed handling of a CEO change. It looks like something or somebody or a group of somebodies blew up. At this point we can only speculate as to why. Stay tuned for today's exciting action...

Topic.Title: Intel Will enter US smartphone market this year

Message.Msg: The FACT is we have 2 foundries (Samsung and Global ) that have tapped out FinFET test chips. Clearly, the FinFET side of things has been resolved. We don't know how good/bad these transistors are to Intel's version and how well (or not) the process will scale. Less Clearly, the FinFET side of things has been resolved. Really? I think you should ask ALTR. There is plenty of publications of Intel TriGate (data, cross sections etc) I have seen NOTHING from Samsung, Glofo or TSMC. No "silicon" just schematics that show show how it should work. Do they have a process? Anyway it's a 20nm chip - it seems ARM foundries have problems with backend which will reduce the ability to shrink. It might not bother the ARM fans but it did bother ALTR.

Message.Title: Bank of America Merrill Lynch - Price Target for Intel - $28 with some Haswell/Bay Trail details
Message.Msg: Meanwhile, Vivek Arya, analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lynch expect that the first quarter sales of Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) would come in a low-end of down 2% -10% guidance vs. current expectation of -6% decline due to the weakening PC demand in Asia particularly after the Chinese new year in February. The analyst expects the PC demand to decline by 15% QoQ. Arya also noted that the timing of Intel’s Haswell ramp could be a critical swing factor. “We expect Haswell to enable sub 10W convertible ultrabooks and tablets with 8-10 hrs battery life, in line with ARM Holdings plc (NASDAQ:ARMH) (LON:ARM), but at performance levels closer to full-featured PCs. Haswell also adds a connected stand-by power state (SOi) to the x86 ecosystem, which brings mobile features to PCs and lowers idle power by 10x and addresses Intel’s Achilles heels vs. ARM. While Intel’s Haswell pricing remains unclear, ultra thin (

Topic.Title: Folks Folks Folks

Message.Msg: I think your information is a little old. Ok, so here is the scoop. Computers and chips sales in general started slowing down in the third quarter of last year. MSFT and INTC sold off because of this. These are both strong buys because of that. Remember, buy low sell high. So essentially you are 2 quarters late. INTC just finished selling the last bit of their excess inventory from the slowdown for the last 2 quarters. Now, INTC is at an earnings trough. Essentially the quarter to be announced earnings will be as bad as it gets. Of course analysts are going to drum beat "that PC sales are slowing down" as much as they can before now and then to get INTC stock as low as it can go. They make money when you churn the stock. IF you listen to this and sell then you are selling at the bottom. Intel missed the whole smart phone thing that is true. They are working hard to catch up but went from to behind to essentially caught up in 2 years time. That while using an outdated core. By the end of the year, Intel chips will be superior to any ARM chip out there. Yes, INTC is quite aware that they need to move aggressively in the mobile space and the are doing it. Buy big tech here, MSFT, INTC, and CSCO this year and you will be very happy at the end of the year.

Message.Title: It May Be Time For Microsoft To Cancel Surface RT
Message.Msg: [I think Microsoft should cancel the RT in July to coincide with Mr. East's departure. Fitting they should leave together...] Cancelling RT and Focusing on Pro To achieve this seemingly uphill battle, Microsoft might need to do away with RT. Initial sales of the RT are weak, while the Pro appears to have sold at a more rapid rate. Consumers do not want a scaled-down tablet running on an ARM-based (ARMH) processor. The opinion of cancelling RT is not unique: IDC mentioned this notion too. The RT Tablet is also powered by NVIDIA (NVDA). The scaled-down operating system appears to weaken the tablet’s strengths: the ability to run x86-based Windows software. Microsoft may have believed that it needed a lower-priced device to compete in the market place. Canceling RT and going “all-in” with Pro would restore Microsoft’s relationship with Intel (INTC). The focus would also bring leadership to hardware manufacturers in building Windows 8-based solutions. From thestreet

Message.Title: East on manufacturing a couple months ago...
Message.Msg: ... he started to contradict himself a couple months ago... and he seems in complete disconnect to the manufacturing aspect though he figured out that cost for ARM SoCs will go up. He does not seem to fully comprehend Moore's law - at least that's what it sounds like In the Intel worldview, a kind of “Transistor Cliff,” if you will, is one very possible end game. To East, it is nonsense. He offers that the things that sell individual chips are “How much does the chip cost, how fast does it go, and how much power does it consume,” considered in concert. If chips can do that in any existing technology, “Why even move to the next node?” “The only benefit of a new geometry is to get more chips out of a wafer,” adds East. But if wafers end up costing twice as much because double patterning — the application of multiple additional “mask layers” — is needed to get to smaller geometries, than the additional cost may outweigh any benefits.

Topic.Title: Intel markets imploding.

Message.Msg: Intel Is the Biggest Bargain Out There: Fort Pitt’s Forrest For anyone who has held shares of Intel (INTC) for more than a decade, chances are the stock has not only been a loser, but also a disappointment. While the world's largest maker of semiconductors has offered traders at least a dozen chances in as many years to try to make money on its price swings between $15 and $25 a share, its long-term story is still a daunting one, including the $75 high-water mark from September of 2000 that still stands today. And yet, analyst Kim Forrest, at Fort Pitt Capital says this time it's going to be different. "At this point in time, I couldn't be happier owning this stock because I really think 2013 is going to be the year in which they begin to show some traction," Forrest says in the attached video. "I think people have really underestimated what this company can produce." Forrest believes Intel can overcome its power efficiency problem sooner than its rivals at ARM (ARMH) can overcome its computing power disadvantage. "My bet is that the engineers at Intel will win this" she says. To gauge how that fight is going, Forrest recommends that investors keep an eye out for any signs of Intel pushing into the lower end smartphone business. Of course, there are plenty of skeptics out there who aren't impressed with the company's 4.3% dividend yield that is high, and rising. In fact, just 35% of the 51 analysts who follow Intel rate it a "buy" right now, which means the stock is the least loved it has been in at least 20 years, FactSet data shows. "Contrarian signals. You gotta love 'em," Forrest says with a smile. From Yahoo Finance

Message.Title: Intel's main competition for it's upcoming set-top box
Message.Msg: The Roku 3 and Apple TV: youtubeDOTcom/watch?v=d69wCtKCATI But these devices don't have what Intel's box will have: - Live TV streaming - Cloud-based DVR Basically, Intel's set-top box will have combined features of a Roku and a TiVo. Big question for me is, will Intel use Android for their UI or will it be their own? I also think Microsoft will have support for Intel's Live TV service on their upcoming Xbox 720. There is also rumor of a Xbox Surface tablet, with Intel inside, that will be used to interact with the game console.

Message.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation
Message.Msg: engadgetDOTcom/2013/03/19/intel-launches-media-server-reference-design/ It seems Intel wants set-top box to be a new device category. So, similar to smartphones and tablets, set-top boxes can be developed using an OS like Android or Windows or Tizen ...and then additional features can be added by each hw maker.

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: The market is bracing for more volatile moves over the next several sessions. First, the FOMC rate decision is due out tomorrow afternoon. The problem with the Fed is that it probably can't get any more dovish than the market currently expects. That leaves the Fed with a choice either to stand pat or to phase out its QE programs. The market could get some short term disappointment. However, should the Fed upgrade its economic forecast, more buyers might come into the stock market. Second, the Cyprus banks will be reopening on Thursday. Regardless what decision or plans the ECB or the Cyprus government come up with, a bank run looks inevitable. These events could keep the volatility high and prices depressed in the stock market. Technically, short term momentum has turned bearish suggesting more pullbacks in the near term.

Message.Title: Weaker PC shipments numbers in China due to Chinese New Year
Message.Msg: This is a factor to consider.

Topic.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation

Message.Msg: Intel normally releases a reference design when they don't intend to make the device themselves. If this is the device that's supposed to be used for Intel Web TV releasing a reference design now may mean the service is far from being ready, especially if they are just now looking for vendors to make it.

Topic.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation

Message.Msg: Intel's vision is for every home to have a Media Server (with Intel inside). The Media Server can be in the form of a set-top/streaming box (like Ruko or Apple TV), or a game console (like Xbox or Wii), or built into the TV (Smart TV). Intel's Live TV service was meant to accelerate this vision since cable operators are happy with the status quo and will not work with any other hw maker. Intel can also generate additional revenue by selling the Live TV service to hardware makers such as Ruko, MS (for the xbox), Sony (nintendo) or Samsung (smart tv). Intel can also use this service as leverage to encourage hardware makers to build their set-top boxes with Intel inside.

Topic.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation

Message.Msg: Intel's set-top box will be used to introduce their Live TV service and also to get the 'ball-rolling' for Media Servers.

Topic.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation

Message.Msg: Hmm. General Instruments defined the set top box in 1982 or thereabouts. Doesn't it seem as if INTC is a little behind these days? I mean, seriously, dozens of companies have done hundreds of set top boxes in the past twenty years. Do you really think they overlooked something? And, the BOM for these things is in the fifteen to twenty five dollar range.

Topic.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation

Topic.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation

Message.Msg: Are you saying that the vendors considering making a box with Intel's reference design will be competing against Intel's box in the marketplace? That's a tough sell to vendors. Additionally, there are plenty of free & open source media server packages that already run on generic Intel PC's. These packages function as DVR's and will stream music & photos throughout the home. With an added HDTV receiver adapter they'll also record live TV. These are called HTPC's and they've been around since the introduction of HDTV.

Topic.Title: Intel launches Media Server Reference Design to speed up set-top box creation

Message.Msg: But I think the idea is to have their Media chip inside Smart TVs. That's where the TV is going. Set-top boxes are sort of temporary devices...eventually Smart TV will have the set-top box functionality built in....and Intel wants to be inside Smart TV.

Message.Title: Nobody retires at age 51.
Message.Msg: I won't read Warren East's retirement as a sign of trouble at ARMH. But just the same nobody ever retires at age 51. Yes there are people who try and after a summer at home with the wife they do something else. My thinking is that he is setting himself up as a corporate superstar. You'll see him slide into some other role sometime in the next year or two as the CEO of another tech company. It's all about timing and what the resume says. Right now his resume looks great. The stock growth story is fabulous and it recently reached record high. He can leave now with an amazing track record and walk into another company while demanding a very lucrative package. The downside in staying is if the stock drops then he has to answer to shareholders. There must be something in the future that has him a bit concerned. He can either leave now while on top or get forced out a couple years from now . I don't see this as a sign that ARMH will be slowing down anytime soon. What I do see is that he's about to get found out that the stories taking over Intel's market won't really come true and the stock will drop because people won't pay sky high premiums for it though the earnings will improve. Warren East isn't the Wizard of Oz but he is the Wizard of Cambridge His resignation ranks up there with the Pope resigning. You won't get the real story but the resignation does make you scratch your head. The real question isn't that he's leaving, but why now?

Topic.Title: Nobody retires at age 51.

Message.Msg: 100% agree.
